intro: Isochilus peruvianus, commonly known as the Peruvian bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, blue or violet flowers. The plant typically grows in high-altitude grasslands and rocky soils, thriving in cool and moist environments. It has narrow, grass-like leaves and produces small, clustered flowers that bloom in the summer months. Due to its ornamental value, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens, though it is relatively rare in cultivation.
